;

不是如果，何时

我相信拜登总统很快就会宣布退出2024年竞选。正如任何看过广告或徽标的人都认为自己是广告和设计方面的专家一样，我也确信自己对环城公路的内部运作有深入的了解。我不。然而，我确实了解男性的自我、家庭动态和情景规划。

拜登阵营一直在讲述的故事是：“事情比他们想象的要好，乔是最好的选择。要么是他，要么是混乱。”

任何叙述都有其自己的生命，上周，叙述如此猛烈地追尾了现实，以至于在安全气囊泄气后，出现了一个令人震惊的停顿，然后迅速变成了恐慌。恐慌才是正确的情绪。我们最担心的事情暴露在我们面前——加上让媒体和管理人员操纵我们的尴尬感。

但沟通是与听众进行的，尽管证据无处不在，但我们民主党人已经进入了自我放逐，远离真相。

拜登参加媒体露面和新闻发布会的次数比近代历史上任何一位总统都少。这是自里根以来最少的一次，里根在 74 岁时开始出现阿尔茨海默氏症的迹象。最后三位赢得连任的总统（克林顿、布什、奥巴马）第二任期开始时的平均年龄为 52 岁。如果他回到宾夕法尼亚大道，他会比拜登年轻三岁。民主党人和媒体向生物学界写了一封愤怒的公开信：年龄歧视。生物学的反应：拿着我的啤酒。

我们怎么可以这么蠢呢？

当前的叙述

现在的叙述是“我是一个老人，更糟糕的是，我是另一个不肯让路的恶性自恋者。”

这在政治上相当于打开收音机，再次听到约翰·传奇的《All of Me》。一次又一次。结果？上周，特朗普在可能选民中的领先优势从3% 上升至 6% ，这对于大多数人已经下定决心的竞选来说是一个重大转变。

多年来，民主党人一直（正确地）说特朗普不适合担任总统。 “好吧，现在拜登也来吧，”宇宙说道。是的，受损的拜登仍然会成为一名更好的第二任总统，但我们可能永远不会知道。现在的民意调查显示，温和派和年轻选民将选择犯罪而不是衰老。真正的问题是特朗普对拜登的辩论表现保持沉默。特朗普迫切希望拜登留在竞选中。如果/当拜登获得提名，并且没有回头路，特朗普媒体机器将把他变成植物人。

志向

野心本身并不是一件坏事。这是创新、财富创造和生活中许多其他美好事物的来源。然而，当它压倒了我们根据事实而不是情感做出决定和行动的（微弱的）能力时，它可能会变得病态。

埃斯蒂斯·凯福弗 (Estes Kefauver) 是一位因对黑手党的调查而闻名的参议员，他有句著名的俏皮话：“总统野心是一种只能通过防腐液才能治愈的疾病。”乔·拜登长期以来一直遇到不好的情况。

在他对 1988 年总统竞选的经典报道《What It Takes 》中，记者理查德·本·克莱默 (Richard Ben Cramer) 援引一名助手的话说，他警告 46 岁的拜登，竞选意味着牺牲朋友、家人和他的整个生活：“你会希望事情变得更糟比任何事情都重要，而且它将接管一切。”拜登的回答基本上是：“我愿意冒这个险。”

在 2020 年的一次竞选活动中，拜登表示：“我将自己视为一座桥梁，而不是其他任何东西。你看到我身后站着整整一代领导人。他们是这个国家的未来。”但从那时起，81 岁的他就坚信自己就是未来。精算图表表明他所剩的（未来）已经不多了。让我们忽略认知能力下降——还有其他因素让治理变得更加困难：死亡。根据精算表，他在第二任期结束前去世的可能性超过三分之一。注：这对特朗普来说并没有好多少，但（提示愤怒/否认机器）他看起来更坚强。

能够优雅地离开是一种天赋，许多其他方面很优秀的人都没有这种能力。面对所有医学和政治证据，露丝·巴德·金斯伯格 (Ruth Bader Ginsburg) 拒绝在民主党提名她的继任者时从最高法院退休，这阻碍了妇女权利的发展。尽管她做了很多好事，但她最终的遗产是她促成了罗伊诉韦德案的推翻。同样，如果拜登今年 11 月输给特朗普，这将是人们对他唯一的记忆。

太快了

一个在社会和职业上被低估的超级大国——以及伟大品牌所做的事情——正在制造一种稀缺感。实现这一目标的最简单方法是尽早离开而不是太晚离开。

为什么聪明人会忽视这些常识性建议？关于人类自欺欺人的能力有大量研究。威廉·S·巴勒斯 (William S. Burroughs) 将人类分为骗子和标记，他直言不讳地说：“世界上的骗子，有一种标记是你无法击败的：内在的标记。”

想象

我们无法想象自己的结局。尝试想象死亡的感觉。你不能，真的不能。你可能会想到黑暗或睡眠，这些你在这一生中实际经历过的事情，但你的大脑对真实的事情没有任何有意义的参考点。因此，我们相信衰落和死亡是为其他人保留的事情。

如果我们在构思和接受宇宙保质期这一任务方面设计得很糟糕，我们就更不可能认识到沿途出现的较小的结局。

政治家和首席执行官尤其不擅长这一点。华盛顿是一个大型的辅助生活社区，充满了富人，他们相信世界没有他们就无法相处，也永远不需要这样做。其结果是，随着老年人不断为自己投更多的钱，繁荣从年轻人向老年人发生了灾难性的转移。正如我之前所写，我们需要更多的年龄歧视，特别是流失。

哈佛商学院教授兰贾伊·古拉蒂 (Ranjay Gulati) 最近告诉《纽约时报》 ，“大多数领导者如果听任自己的安排，将无法识别离开的正确时机。当每个人都告诉你你是对的时，你真的很难保持脚踏实地和谦虚。”

思考

这让我们回到了特朗普这个真正的坏人可能连任的可能性。拜登，一个真正正派的人，让他的自我赌上了我们所有的未来。他愿意这样做反映了人类的共同弱点。但这并不能减少它的错误或自私。他和他的家人将自己的希望/愿望置于国家的希望之上。然而，我相信他在辩论中的灾难性表现引发了一场对话和清算，这可能会在本周末导致拜登家族决定他应该退出。

为什么？大坝溃决了。辩论结束后，科技/媒体/国会/政党中最有影响力的声音（即《纽约时报》里德·霍夫曼、南卡罗来纳州众议员詹姆斯·克莱伯恩、佩洛西、奥巴马）都开始——尽可能温和地——开始建议他应该退出。就像一个意识到自己即将被抛弃而无法停止发送短信的青少年男孩或女孩一样，拜登阵营在过去 24 小时内向我发送了 8 封电子邮件，向我保证他们“会赢得胜利”。最糟糕的是，效忠者们试图在网上羞辱人们，让他们把头抬起来——“喘口气，坐下来，90 分钟并不能定义总统职位，”等等。

说真的……醒醒。这。他妈的。向上。

替代者

最有可能取代拜登的两位候选人是副总统哈里斯和加州州长纽瑟姆。没有其他人具有知名度。

在接力棒传递后一周内，任何一个人的民调支持率都会大幅上升。品牌就是差异化，与特朗普形成鲜明对比。两人都没有参与叛乱，没有被判对性虐待负有责任，也没有强迫五分之一需要终止妊娠的妇女离开自己的州。而且，最明显的是，两人都是在特朗普大学毕业并为父亲工作时出生的。

哈里斯将是最无缝的，因为从技术上讲，拜登筹集的 25 亿美元也是她的。此外，这个国家似乎终于准备好迎接一位女总统了，而且自这场灾难以来，她似乎已经找到了自己的声音。最后，尽管她没有以副总统的身份脱颖而出，但她是一位强有力的总检察长和参议员。这表明她可能更适合担任行政职务。

纽瑟姆是直接从中央铸造出来的，是在一家工厂里用来自较小候选者的零件制造的。他已经是一个（经济上）比印度、法国或英国更大的国家的总统。他是一位出色的辩论家。最后，他很性感——人们更有可能为他们想与之发生性关系的候选人投票和拉票。纽瑟姆是令特朗普感到害怕的候选人。

场景规划

情景规划并不是试图预测未来，而是想象几种可能的未来，并确定在几种未来中获得最佳结果的行动方案。而且，在我看来，大多数/所有道路都会导致拜登总统下台。民意调查显示，现状将导致特朗普获胜——以下是三种替代情景以及每种情景对拜登家族意味着什么的猜测：

1 .拜登退出，特朗普落选

拜登巩固了他作为伟大总统之一的遗产，在进入任何房间时都会受到起立鼓掌。他的余生是所有胜利圈之母。当民意调查谁应该被添加到拉什莫尔山时，他就在候选名单上。

2.拜登退出，特朗普获胜

我不认为这是一个现实的场景。或者更具体地说，我不想考虑它。 （这些是我的设想。）无论如何，如果这一切成为现实，没有人会要求拜登负责尝试做正确的事情。

3.拜登留任/获胜

这让我相信他会在未来几天退出。约瑟夫·拜登和他的家人经历了巨大的损失。很难了解一个家庭的具体动态，但可以肯定的是，他的家人非常爱他。对于他们的丈夫/父亲/兄弟来说，最糟糕的结果不会是输给特朗普——这将是第二个任期。他的生活将变成一场精心设计的舞蹈，家庭和助手试图将他从公众视野中隔离出来。当他屈服于一个无法击败的敌人时，他每天都会经历无数次私人和公开的小羞辱。 （参见上文：生物学。）

留任可能是他想要的，也是拜登家族认为他们想要的。但是，在一定距离后，他的亲人会认识到，继续参加比赛会带来两种结果：糟糕和更糟。说真的，对于我们这些照顾八十多岁父母的人来说……想象一下他的生活，如果他获胜的话，在接下来的四年半里。我不相信他的家人会让这种事发生在他身上。

我认为爱在这里获胜。

生活如此丰富，

帖子《离开的时间》首先出现在《无情/无恶意》上。

我在一个黑暗的地方。当一个骗子虐待一个老人时，我目睹了民主的崩溃。我还没有跌入谷底，所以让我们讨论一下社交媒体和年龄限制。

成瘾和影响

社交媒体的影响力和令人上瘾的潜力是前所未有的——就像一个可以装在口袋里的无底多巴袋。对于孩子来说，这会带来更大的风险。证据是压倒性的，并且已经存在了一段时间了。只是花了一点时间才意识到这些谎言是多么厚颜无耻——“我们为我们的进步感到自豪。”社交媒体可能很危险。这并不意味着它是“坏”的——它还有很多好处。但与汽车、酒精和 AK-47 类似，它对我们的生活有着复杂的影响。它带来了危险。健康社会所做的事情之一就是限制儿童获得危险产品，因为儿童缺乏安全使用危险产品的能力。然而，进入社交媒体时代二十年后，我们允许所有年龄段的人无限制地访问这种危险的、令人上瘾的产品。原因是：激励。具体来说，这些平台没有动力对其产品进行年龄限制，从而为任何限制访问的努力注入沙子。要改变结果，我们必须改变激励措施。

成人游泳

当我喝酒时，我会变得更好、更有趣、更有兴趣。我进行大量锻炼的原因之一是这样我可以继续喝酒——肌肉比脂肪更能吸收酒精。孩子们是不同的，我们长期以来一直乐于以不同的方式对待他们。 1838 年，威斯康星州禁止未经父母同意向未成年人出售酒类，到 1900 年，规定最低饮酒年龄的州法律已很普遍。有充分的理由表明，美国 21 度的酒精限量太高，但没有人会认为我们应该完全戒除有年龄限制的饮酒。

这种趋势与限制儿童接触其他事物的法律并行。宪法规定了携带武器的权利，但法院却毫不犹豫地阻止儿童获得枪支，尽管他们取消了对枪支拥有权的所有其他限制。如果有游说团体试图向 13 岁的孩子发放驾驶执照，我找不到。同意年龄法律将与儿童发生性行为定为犯罪；未成年人不得签订合同；我们限制他们的工作时间和条件；他们不能参军或担任陪审团成员，也不能投票。 （我们可能需要重新考虑最后一个。）这些都不是微不足道的事情。相反，我们将儿童排除在外或严重限制他们参与社会的许多核心活动。

与 Dawg 共度深夜

我唯一一次出现在深夜电视节目中是吉米·法伦 (Jimmy Fallon) 嘲笑我时播放的CNN 视频片段，其中我说“我宁愿给我 16 岁的孩子一瓶杰克和大麻，也不愿给 Instagram”。 4000 次点赞和 265,000 次观看后，美国似乎也同意了。我现在快 17 岁的儿子已经接触了这三种物质。酒精和 Instagram 让他事后感觉更糟——不确定大麻是否如此。然而，他被限制在口袋里携带一瓶杰克酒，如果他的脸被密封在烟枪上，他的父母会要求他说一句话。注意：别再给我那些孩子假期不回家的非父母或治疗师提出的废话育儿建议。

他、我们和社会限制他接触这些物质。而且，当他戒酒/戒烟时，他并没有脱离所有的社会接触和同龄人的结缔组织。当我们在他的一台设备上发现色情内容（如果你有男孩的话，你就会这么做）时，我们吓坏了。但研究很明确：当我们在他的手机上发现 Instagram/Snap/TikTok 时，我们应该更加警惕。马克·扎克伯格和谢丽尔·桑德伯格是全球经济的色情制造者。事实上，这对于色情工作者来说是不公平的。

同辈压力

年龄限制的社交媒体非常受欢迎。超过 80% 的成年人认为使用社交媒体应该需要父母的同意，近 70% 的成年人希望平台限制未成年人在社交媒体上花费的时间。

这些数字是去年秋天的数据，当时我的纽约大学同事乔纳森·海特 (Jonathan Haidt) 出版了《焦虑的一代》(The Anxious Generation) ，该书以让·特温格 (Jean Twenge)等人的工作为基础，提出了迄今为止最有力的论据，证明社交媒体正在伤害我们的孩子。海特教授回顾了我们的孩子正在经历的抑郁、自残和普遍痛苦的惊人增加以及平台辩护者提供的解释，强调了社交媒体和移动设备的双重幽灵以及它们对一代人造成的持久伤害。海特指出，不受限制地使用智能手机是“人类对自己的孩子进行的最大规模的不受控制的实验”。结果出来了。

立法机构正在做出回应。从加利福尼亚州到犹他州再到路易斯安那州，各州都通过了根据年龄限制使用社交媒体的法律。然而，如果您没有注意到这些平台的行为有任何变化，那是因为法院已经屏蔽了几乎所有平台。一个名为NetChoice的社交媒体和数字商务贸易组织很快就会起诉任何干涉其成员剥削儿童以获取最大利润的能力的国家。

“复杂的”

法官们站在平台一边，可能并不是因为他们喜欢看到抑郁的青少年被灌输美化自残的内容，或者十几岁的男孩在受到性勒索后自杀。这些法律的平台和其他反对者，例如美国公民自由联盟，提出了两个主要观点：首先，他们声称在线验证年龄过于复杂，需要收集有关用户的各种信息，并且在所有情况下都不起作用。 。其次，要求用户收集这些信息会产生言论自由、隐私和安全问题。 （这些平台还否认他们的产品对儿童有害。）

从表面上看，这些观点是正确的。在网上确认年龄比较困难，因为柜台上没有工作人员可以要求查看您的驾驶执照并参考您的面部信息。事实证明，这些平台对个人数据的处理是不计后果的。这有点像“他们如此不负责任，但我们无法采取行动”的困境。

但这些反对意见与年龄验证、儿童权利、言论自由或隐私无关。他们担心平台公司的能力。他们的论点归根结底是这样的断言：这些耗资数十亿美元的组织聚集了庞大的人力资本，掌握着神圣的技术，却无法弄清楚如何建立有效、高效、符合宪法的年龄验证系统来保护儿童。如果这听起来像废话，请相信你的直觉。

复杂性的错觉

这不是关于可能性领域的对话，而是关于有利可图的领域的对话。当你付钱让一个行业不了解某件事时，它永远不会明白。 （只要看看烟草业就无法发现与癌症的联系。）更具挑战性的是，确定某人是否小于 16 岁，或者建立一个全球实时通信网络来存储近乎无限量的文本、视频、数十亿并发用户可以在几毫秒内检索音频，并且 24/7 正常运行时间？社交媒体巨头知道你在哪里、你在做什么、你的感受如何，以及你是否有自杀意念……但他们无法计算出你的年龄。这事你编不出来。

这些平台可以设计出可靠地收集足够信息来确认用户年龄的技术，然后从服务器上删除这些信息。他们可以创建一个私人或公共实体来匿名处理年龄验证。还记得区块链吗？这不正是它应该解决的问题吗？他们可以部署人工智能，根据用户的在线行为来估计用户何时可能未成年，并向高危人群寻求年龄验证。如果设备制造商（或者只是苹果和 Alphabet 的设备操作系统双寡头）得到适当的激励，他们可以在设备本身上实现年龄验证。 （这就是 Meta 所说的它想要的，当它不反对年龄验证要求时。）或者，疯狂的想法，他们可以停止美化自杀并向每个人推销色情内容。

扎克和其他轴心国势力没有在他们的平台上建立年龄验证的原因是，这会减少他们的利润（因为他们会向孩子们提供更少的广告），这会压低他们的股价，而上市公司首席执行官的工作是来提高股价。句号，句号，战略计划结束。只要青少年自杀和抑郁症的不良公关对股价造成的负面影响小于通过对这些青少年进行无限制的算法操纵而获得的增量广告收入的积极影响，理性的、股东驱动的做法就是对抗年龄验证要求。

翻转脚本

如果我们希望平台让他们的产品对儿童来说是安全的，我们需要改变激励措施——迫使他们承担损害的成本。用经济学家的话说，将外部性内部化。三种力量足以做到这一点：市场、原告律师和政府。市场的解决方案是让消费者决定他们是否愿意被剥削和操纵。我所说的消费者是指“青少年”。这种方法的一大缺点是青少年都是白痴。我这里有证据，因为我养了两只，以前是一只。作为他们的父亲，我的工作就是成为他们的前额皮质，直到它出现为止。我星期四告诉儿子今天是星期四，他不同意。

下一个方法是让平台为所欲为，但如果他们伤害了某人，就让那个人起诉他们要求赔偿。这就是我们在几乎所有情况下监管产品安全的方式。你的汽车安全气囊是否有爆炸碎片击中你的脖子？ 高田苏。滑石粉会致癌吗？苏强生。你的手机有没有烧伤你腿上的皮肤？告三星。人们不喜欢原告律师，但诉讼是更多产品不会致癌或烫伤的一个重要原因。然而，没有人能够成功起诉社交媒体平台，因为一项已有 28 年历史的法律（称为“第 230 条”）为社交媒体平台提供了针对诉讼的全面保护。

我之前写过关于限制第 230 条的必要性的文章，每当我这样做时，言论自由绝对主义者的僵尸末日就会被释放。然而，这一主张保持不变：如果社交媒体平台认为他们已经采取了一切合理措施来保护儿童免受其产品的危险，那么就让他们在法庭上证明这一点。或者，更好的是，让对烟草/石棉型诉讼侵吞他们的利润的恐惧促使他们对他们的产品进行年龄限制。

最后，政府可以追查其产品损害消费者的公司。联邦贸易委员会因侵犯隐私而对 Meta 处以 50 亿美元的罚款，但没有明显效果。这是完美的，只是少了一个 0。对于这些公司来说，50 亿美元是一种麻烦，而不是一种威慑。参议院目前有一项法案，即《 儿童在线安全法案》 ，该法案将赋予联邦贸易委员会新的权力，以追查未能为儿童建立护栏的平台。这并非没有风险——一些右翼团体支持它，因为他们认为它可以用来压制 LGBT 内容或父权制认为不受欢迎的任何其他内容。但我对国会完善法律的能力更有信心，而不是对社交平台在没有法律的情况下进行变革的意愿更有信心。

除非我们改变激励措施并将这些平台的成本归咎于平台本身，否则它们不会改变。试图设计年龄限制系统或为平台制定详细政策的立法者正在玩傻瓜游戏。社交媒体公司可以在每一项立法中找出漏洞，资助无休无止的诉讼，并部署他们的游说大军和人造隔热罩（ Lean In ），同时让他们的系统变得更加容易上瘾和剥削。

或者也许我们错了，我们应该让我们的孩子喝酒、开车，并在 12 岁时参军。割腕后，幸存者通常会纹身来遮盖伤疤。也许青少年应该跳过社交媒体，只去纹身。我警告过你……黑暗。

生活如此丰富，

人工智能自助洗衣店

我在戛纳，宿醉的时候，我去了雅虎海滩，看了烟鬼乐队。戛纳是我在二三十岁时想要的一切，但却无法进入，因为我他妈的一直在工作，没有钱，也没有影响力。我想晚一点比较好。无论如何，今年戛纳广告大会最大的两个故事将是：

1. Musk/Yaccarino 的道歉巡演，与 Milli Vanilli 出现在 Spotify Beach 相比，这次巡演的反响稍冷一些。

“不，埃隆，真的，你可以去操你自己了。” –广告社区

2. 我的朋友 Michael Kassan 在露台上主持他的新公司 3C 的启动晚宴，俯瞰着他以前的公司 MediaLink 的派对。专业提示：有卵巢的首席执行官不会做这种事。 “鸡巴”动作的定义。我昨天在与迈克尔的小组讨论中（逐字）说了这一点，他回答说：“你的意思是，这是一个大动作。”

但。一、离题。

视觉事物

最好的创始人阐明了未来的愿景，并将公司的商业模式置于其核心。这与好莱坞没有什么不同——场景和服装在变化，但乌托邦/反乌托邦未来的承诺是不变的。顺便说一句，最能描述我们世界的标题是“平均而言，今天全球情况略有好转”。但这是令人厌恶的。具有讽刺意味的是，热门电影趋势似乎是关于商业的传记片，特别是关于成功产品的传记片。工作室高管最近批准了有关黑莓、俄罗斯方块、Air Jordan 的电影，大概在食用食品之后，还有辛辣的奇多和果馅饼。随着一切的金融化（首席执行官们纷纷签名乳房）成为七级飓风，预计有关人工智能超级恶棍的电影将会出现猛烈冲击。

在最新的《碟中谍》系列（航位推测第一部分）中，反派是一个有感知力的人工智能实体，名为……等等……“实体”。我自己正在制作一部电影，考虑到我的好莱坞职业生涯，它很快就会在影院上映。或许。

人工智能重写

在美国，金钱就是相关性——而现在世界上最相关的事情就是一家设计 GPU 的公司。英伟达的市值增长创历史新高（仅去年一年就达到了 2 万亿美元），短暂成为世界上最有价值的公司，因为它的芯片是人工智能革命的真正核心。不需要讲故事。我很欣赏 NVDA 的人来到戛纳，不像 GOOG/META 那样，先用手指抚摸媒体高管的头发，然后朝他们的脸开枪。我最喜欢的戛纳时刻：谢丽尔 2013 年的签名售书活动，吸引了数百名女性高管，尽管她的公司让数百万少女感到沮丧。

回到英伟达。想一想：一家公司在 12 个月内增加了全球汽车工业的价值和瑞典的 GDP。 OpenAI 及其甜心爸爸微软也同样受益。但少数企业无法满足投资者对人工智能故事的渴望。 CNBC 每年都会评选出 50 家最具颠覆性公司，2024 年榜单上三分之二的公司“将人工智能描述为对其业务‘至关重要’”。这句话中的关键词是“描述”。每一位能拼出“AI”（即所有人）的通讯主管和首席执行官都认为人工智能是他们公司故事的主角。然而，与《权力的游戏》类似，许多男主角和女主角都无法进入第二季。

这让我想到了坦帕斯。我的意思是……Tempus AI 。

Tempus 是一家基因组测试和数据公司。医生从患者身上采集血液或组织样本，并将其送到 Tempus 实验室，然后 Tempus 发回有关在这些样本中发现的基因的信息。除了测试之外，Tempus 还将其收集的数据授权给制药公司，制药公司使用这些数据来开发药物。 Tempus 专攻癌症，这是一项伟大的事业，因为抗击癌症是一件崇高的事情。人工智能、医疗保健、癌症……迪斯科。我给首席执行官发了电子邮件——我（有点）认识他；给我的印象是一个令人印象深刻的人——并问我是否可以投资。他说他们只让机构投资（有道理）。然而，我仍然感兴趣，所以我进一步了解了该公司（阅读：我要求我的团队调查该公司），以下是我们的发现：

从赚钱的意义上来说，这并不是一个伟大的生意。 Tempus不赚钱，它烧钱。自2015年成立以来，该公司已筹集了15亿美元的风险资金，并且几乎全部花光。根据其 IPO 文件，截至 3 月 31 日，Tempus 的银行存款还剩 8000 万美元。而且它每周烧钱 800 万美元，这表明它上周将耗尽现金。该公司于 4 月底从软银那里额外筹集了 2 亿美元，否则它可能无法参加 IPO。我想知道中央情报局什么时候会在莫斯科安插软银、查马斯·帕利哈皮蒂亚和凯西·伍德来削弱俄罗斯经济。

腾邦AI跌跌撞撞地冲过IPO终点线，掉进了一堆钱里。它的定价为 37 美元，开盘价为 40 美元，最高触及 44 美元，最后收于 38 美元，一天交易后，该公司的市值达到 60 亿美元。一次可观的 IPO 冲击，以及4.11 亿美元的支票（又名烧钱的一年）。该估值低于 Tempus 80 亿美元的私募市场估值，但 11 倍的收入倍数仍高于其竞争对手，例如 Guardant 和 NeoGenomics，其交易价格分别为 6 倍和 2.7 倍。 （Guardant 在 IPO 前三天通过专利诉讼欢迎 Tempus 进入公开市场。见上文：迪克举动。）

一家在竞争激烈的市场中面临专利诉讼的亏损企业，其前任公司Groupon在烧掉了 15 亿美元投资者资金后，其股价仅为 IPO 估值的 6%，其经营者是如何获得近乎两倍的市盈率的？它最有价值的竞争对手？答：当人们手头有现金时，永远不要低估市场提供产品/故事的能力。在这种情况下，很可能（再次）是投资者受到了打击。

Tempus 在其 IPO 文件中提及 AI 228 次，去年甚至将这些字母添加到其名称末尾。值得注意的是，该公司于 2021 年首次申请 IPO，当时提及人工智能78 次。 AI炒作是指Tempus凳子的第三站，即“ AI应用程序”产品线。这个想法是，Tempus将其实验室测试与对患者的整个记录​​的全面审查（其他测试结果，医生的笔记，家族病史，药物等）相结合，并为患者护理提供建议。 AI医生。这听起来很棒，但也是科幻（即幻想）。这是因为AI应用程序目前可提供公司收入的2％。 Tempus没有时间将“ AI”添加到其徽标上，其网站唯一包含新名称的部分是投资者关系部分。 S-1的读物就像是由LLM撰写的风险投资宣传甲板，并在以下提示中写道：“将30分钟的幻灯片呈现给我们的IPO路演，将我们定位为AI公司。”第二提示：如果牛铃是AI，则“更多牛铃”。

旋转周期

我无法决定是否应该批评tempus或赞扬。市场想要AI公司，Tempus想要市场的资本，并通过AI洗涤将贸易配对。每个人都在这样做，并且公司吸引廉价资本的能力可能会提供类固醇将其从卡尔·刘易斯（Carl Lewis）转变为本·约翰逊（Ben Johnson）。 Tempus AI不是第一个玩这个名字游戏的公司：C3.AI以常规的“ C3”开始生活，将咖啡作为“ C3 Energy”，并以“ The-Thans Internet”的潮流为“ C3iot”在公开以C3.AI的公开状态之前

在英国，最大的国内能源公司章鱼自2001年以来就已经估价了近2倍，其首席执行官无法停止谈论AI 。星巴克正在利用AI“ 培养人类精神”，Kellog颁发了“ Mbai ”商学院学位。在我的在线ED创业公司部分，我们提供了AI学院，但我们没有将名称更改为section.ai。 （尽管GoDaddy仅以$ 798,888的价格出售URL……价格为2倍的估值颠簸。）即使是实际的洗衣机也在游戏中：LG在2020年介绍了一台AI驱动的洗衣机。高盛银行家将洗衣机带到每台洗衣机路演。

我们以前去过这里，周期总是在转弯。最近是加密货币，以及一切的nfterification 。 90年代后期的Dot-Com Boom看到了包括Drkoop.com在内的企业， 这是前外科医生C. Everett Koop的网站，该网站在2001年在其纳斯达克IPO之前占据了38％的速度。

有些迹象表明，AI洗涤的黄金时代从旋转周期开始放缓 - 结束。监管机构正在关注。 SEC以六位数的罚款击中了两名投资顾问，因为他们声称在其财务预测中使用AI。该机构的执法负责人明确表示，这是对公开交易的公司的警告：“公开发行人对AI采用的索赔也必须保持警惕，对类似的错误陈述可能是个人投资决定的重要性。”

SEC还提出了针对已故的招聘人员Joonko的欺诈指控，该指控声称使用AI来识别不同的申请人，但去年，当其创始人被揭露以使其人数夸大并策划了伪造的证词时。 FTC希望公司知道它正在关注他们的AI主张，而FDA正在考虑规范在医疗保健中使用AI模型。该市场最喜欢的公民助理Hindenburg Research最近在Equinix上指出了卖空的枪支， 指责数据中心提供商出售“ AI Pipe Dream”。

Tempus AI的IPO可能是AI洗涤周期结束的最新信号，因为其谦虚，预制的POP已经蒸发。 C3.ai的股票已经从2021年的IPO后高80％。

空气干燥

AI机会和AI洗涤之间的界线既不清楚也不固定。当然，对于异常值来说，很明显 - NVIDIA将继续注册上空的AI，而声称使用AI选择股票的阴暗经纪人不会。但是对于大多数公司而言，清晰度只会出现事后。具有讽刺意味的是，一年前的大故事是如何检测某人是否在使用AI（ 新闻报道， 学生论文，律师）。今天，我们试图辨别公司是否不使用AI。

生活如此丰富，

Subject: You got this

America, and the Western alliance it leads, is dysfunctional. It's also less dysfunctional than any other society.为什么？ America's alchemy of individualism, rights, education, innovation, capital, diversity, entrepreneurship and generosity creates a substance found elsewhere but not at this potency. I spend a great deal of time digesting data and media. And there's a fissure between them. The data reflects a cold but comforting truth: The hand you've been dealt is better than you've been told.

There are paths to prosperity in our imperfect economy. There are paths to love and lasting relationships in our imperfect society. There are paths to fulfillment and meaning in our imperfect culture. The paths are there, and we collectively have an obligation to make the investments to ensure they stay broad and illuminated. However, you must walk them. Much of your future is outside of your control, but if you're a graduate of an American university (the finest in the world), then more of it is in your control than nearly anybody else. What ultimately dictates your success relative to your environment is the choice you make to walk, and the resilience you find to keep moving. In a word, agency.

Agent You

Agency is the capacity to take the actions of your choosing, and through those actions shape your future and the world you live in. More than that, it is the recognition that you have the potency to make it happen. Agency is a fundamental aspect of human autonomy and identity. Individuals who perceive themselves as agents are more motivated, capable, and resilient. A society made up of immigrants has superior genes — they have DNA that naturally connects risks, and a propensity toward action, with better outcomes. I think, as a dad, one of my responsibilities is to help my sons connect actions, good and bad, with outcomes. To help them develop pattern recognition between action and reaction.

Gen Data

Pundits and policymakers have a fetish for statistics. “Women between 25 and 34 eat three times more yogurt than men older than 45 who make under $62,000 per year.” “The lowest income quartile of US households use debit cards at Walmart on holiday weekends more often than the top three quartiles combined.” I spend much of my professional life looking at data sets and making broad generalizations. Many of which are not encouraging. However, you are one data point … not the set.

You are not your cohort. You are not sentenced to be the average of your peers, the median of your race, or the mean of your gender. Agency begins with this insight. Within the mass of humans lumped together by statisticians, on several dimensions, you are an outlier. Your range of possible outcomes is invisible to the statistician's eye. Statistics are observations, not conclusions.

Big Pie

The pie of economic prosperity is not sliced evenly. It skews toward certain fields and backgrounds, and increasingly toward incumbents. Ours is a winner-take-most economy. Jeff Bezos' net worth ($200 billion) is 100,000 times that of the median cardiologist ($2 million). Bezos is a brilliant entrepreneur, but he's not 100,000 times more so than a doctor who literally holds patients' lives in their hands. And while Bezos is the prime mover, Amazon's value creation requires the work of 1.5 million employees, of whom only a handful enjoy a net worth 1/10,000th the size of Bezos' ($20 million).

Yet even as our system allocates $200 billion to Bezos, there is more pie to go around. The US economy generates $27 trillion in annual output, and more every year. That's a prosperity volcano. In 2019 less than 10 million US families had more than $1 million in wealth. In 2022 it was 16 million. We increased the number of millionaire households by 60% in just three years. This is mainly self-made wealth. Only 21% of American millionaires have received any inheritance, the same percentage as the population at large. There are 600,000 millennial millionaire households, and “ while the average millennial has 30% less wealth at the age of 35 than baby boomers did at the same age … the top 10% of millennials have 20% more wealth than the top baby boomers at the同龄。” In sum, we have inordinate income inequality, and that's bad. However, the silver lining is the scales are tipped toward those who bring a sense of agency. If the previous sentence sounds as if I'm putting lipstick on a pig, trust your instincts. Still, there's a lot of prosperity.

Paths to Prosperity

Many cultures and economic systems suppress agency, pushing people toward conformity, often to the benefit of existing elites. Ground zero for a lack of agency is the culture supported by the zombie apocalypse of useful idiots on campuses.但我离题了。 Last week on Prof G Markets , my co-host Ed Elson made a powerful point about the UK, where he grew up. His school gives two kinds of grades, one for the quality of the work and one for effort. Officially, the “best” grade was to score at the top in both categories. But the culture rewarded something else: The true best grade went to the student who got the highest mark on quality and the lowest mark for effort. Success should be accidental; striving is uncouth. Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson personified this — a man of undeniable brilliance who was utterly committed to the culture of non-effort, reflected in a highly manicured image of dishevelment.

Who succeeds in a culture that discourages agency? The incumbents, those who already have wealth. Agency is churn, the essence of upward mobility. Caste systems are meant to relieve you of existential stress, because agency has a dark side. In America, the view/belief that you can accomplish anything implicitly whispers in your ears that, if you don't, it's your own fault.

America offers unprecedented agency. That is why millions of people walk across continents to reach this place, and why we spend billions militarizing our southern border to keep the inflow manageable. Pro tip: America has not only benefited from immigration, but illegal immigration specifically , because the undocumented do dirty jobs at modest wages, pay taxes, and use fewer resources. Anyone who tells you immigrants are here for a handout is taking you for a fool. People don't walk through jungles and traverse rivers for a welfare check. They come for the same reason my parents crossed the Atlantic in a steamship: to exercise their agency. Open borders are unacceptable, and a security threat, but we need to have a sober conversation re why we have turned a blind eye to illegal immigration for 40 years. Hint: money.

Nowhere can a business idea attract so much funding ( $260 billion in VC last year, $50 billion in SBA loans) or recruit so much talent (nearly 60,000 new Ph.Ds per year, 120,000 MBAs). These resources attract high-agency individuals — 5.5 million small business applications were filed in the US in 2023, a record number that's nearly doubled in the past eight years. Living in London, when speaking at an event, people usually ask me to compare/contrast the US/UK It's fairly simple. Some people thought it was a good idea to leave everything behind, and get on a boat. Others thought it was a stupid idea and stayed. Fast forward a couple centuries and Americans are 25% more likely to start a business with access to five times the venture capital .

We live in an era of unprecedented reach. This is not limited to the US, but the US is the epicenter. If you have something to say and a compelling way to say it, you can reach hundreds of millions of people without gatekeepers or sponsors. In 2012, Jimmy Donaldson was a 13-year-old with a YouTube channel. Today, MrBeast is 26 and has a YouTube channel … with a $48 million production budget reaching hundreds of millions and generating $700 million in annual revenue. Entertainers, activists, and commentators from Greta Thunberg and Liza Koshy to X González and Charli D'Amelio have exercised their agency to achieve global influence without relying on traditional gatekeepers.

This is a profound shift. Before he became “the most trusted man in America,” Walter Cronkite edited his high school paper, worked on his college paper, called baseball games on the radio for two years, spent nearly a decade reporting on WWII from Europe for UPI, and worked for another decade hosting a slew of news and opinion shows for CBS before finally getting the anchor chair of the CBS Evening News in 1962. He was 52 years old. Before Samuel L. Jackson became the highest-grossing actor of all time, he performed Off-Broadway for 16 years; then another unknown, Spike Lee, started casting him in small film roles; and it was another six years of minor parts before Pulp Fiction made him a star.他今年 46 岁。 You can get further, faster in the US in our era than in any place or time in history.直到明天。 The bad news is there are more people with more agency (ie, competition) and a crowding of spoils to the winners.

Agency is not individuality. You exercise agency whenever you make a choice to shape your own life. Choosing marriage is exercising agency. Asking for more responsibility at work, or volunteering at a local institution, or putting $100 a month into an IRA — these are all choices to act and shape the world. Using social media to connect to people and share ideas can be an exercise of agency; scrolling TikTok all evening is not. The stoics taught us to focus on what is in our control. Agency is an embrace, and broadening, of what is in our control.

Passivity Party

America rewards agency, but American politics is experiencing a crisis of passivity. For generations, conservatism served as a bulwark of personal responsibility against the left's nanny-state tendencies. The modern Republican party, however, has embraced the brand of victimhood. Its leaders have figured out the best way to be heard is to claim they've been censored. Censored … give me a fucking break .

这是一种行为。 The leader of the GOP owns his own social network. The nation's self-appointed protector of free speech from the woke mob owns another. The wealthiest and most powerful tech bros find common cause in their victimization. Meanwhile, on the left, cataloging and obsessing over every historical wrong ignores our progress and (worse) robs young people of their agency, leaving too many believing the die has been cast re their fate.不，还没有。

Besides being no way to govern, leaning into the rhetoric of victimhood suppresses agency. If you tell people from an early age they are doomed, you will suppress their confidence and increase the likelihood they won't try.他们为什么会这么做？ Agency and democracy go hand in hand, and the first task of the authoritarian leader is to diminish agency. The likely misinformation lollapalooza surrounding this fall's election won't be advocating for a specific candidate or position, but flooding the zone with so much misinformation that people feel overwhelmed and decide just to stay home. The Biden team has stated that their real competition is the couch.

I-agency

More than elections, or your career, your well-being and happiness are a function of your relationships. One of my biggest mistakes, something that's stood between me and a sense of peace and reward, is not recognizing that I had the power to protect, repair and enhance my relationships. More than “find your passion” (bullshit), or other advice some formerly important person, dressed up as a kitchen utensil vomited at you at commencement … this is what I wish I had known post-graduation:

Don't keep score.

Whenever I felt I was in the minus column re a relationship (ie, giving more than I was getting), I would be frustrated and inject disappointment and anger into the relationship. However, we all naturally inflate our contributions and diminish the other party's. In addition, relationships are a give-and-take and rarely in perfect balance. Decide what type of friend, lover, son, colleague you want to be … and put away the scorecard. Rather than constantly revisiting if/when my dad was there for me as a kid, I now just focus on being the son I want to be.这是一种解放。

注意。

Your job in an intimate relationship is to show up, to give witness to someone's life. That you notice. Sometimes you need to push back, or offer a solution. However, I've found, most of the time, our job is to notice. To care that the person is upset, to listen, to empathize with their upset and register how much their happiness and well-being mean to you. I am exceptionally rational, and this has been a superpower professionally. But it's been a weakness personally, as I believe there are a series of steps to fix and understand everything. When the better solution is just to listen … and notice.

Forgive/check yourself.

You do have agency, more than you think. But a cruel truth is that much of what happens to you is in fact out of your control. My best decision was to be born in 1960s California. So try hard and be kind. But when things go poorly and you are hurt, really hurt (heartbroken, laid off, make poor investments, lose someone you love), realize there are millions of people who've experienced the exact same thing and gone on to live wonderful lives. On the flip side, realize that when you get promoted, register professional success, or find yourself in a good relationship, you should acknowledge (again) much of this isn't your fault, and you should be grateful and lower your risk profile. You are never more susceptible to a big mistake than after a big win, as you fall under the delusion that it's (all) you … vs. good fortune.

有限。

“Wow, life has gone SO slowly,” said nobody, ever. My superpower is atheism … no kidding. I believe, at some point, I will look into my son's eyes and know our relationship is coming to an end.没关系。 I like what the great philosopher Mae West said: “You only live once. But if you do it right, once is enough.” This belief in the end has unlocked the courage to take risks and (mostly) ignore social constructs that get in the way of coloring outside of the lines or risking embarrassment expressing my emotions. I got emotional on the Chris Wallace show yesterday. I was discussing some of the men who mentored me when I was a boy, and felt a rush of embarrassment. Jesus Christ, who cares? When on my deathbed, I will find comfort in having lived out loud, even if that meant shedding a few tears on CNN.

We are a mite on an unremarkable rock circling a pedestrian star in one of 200 billion solar systems that make up billions of galaxies. You are insignificant and remarkable all at once. To dwell on your failures, not take risks, and not love and register the beauty around you with reckless abandon fails to recognize a universal truth: Everything and everyone you're worried about will be gone soon, really soon. This is your instant, your moment. Why wouldn't you be kind to yourself, love others, forgive yourself, forgive others and create joy for you and your loved ones wherever, whenever possible? Your heartbreak, disappointment, and grief will be the receipts for the joy and the agency you forge. Heartbreak, disappointment, grief, joy … I wish for you all of these things.

生活如此丰富，

Today it's the third-most-valuable company on Earth, with a dominant 80% share in AI chips, the processers underpinning the largest, fastest creation of value in history ( $8 trillion ). Last year, at Cannes, Jensen Huang introduced himself to me and said “I love your videos.” Not recognizing him, I asked if he'd like a photo.他说是的，我们拍了张照片，然后我继续走。自那时起，他的公司价值增加了​​ 1.3 万亿美元。我进行了氯胺酮治疗，戒酒 17 天，并仅在 YouTube 的帮助下安装了路由器。 It's been a big year for both of us.

There is near-universal agreement on the AI market's revolutionary potential, a historic consensus that explains the upward trajectory of AI stocks. In sum, everyone is barking up the same tree … which makes us stupid. It also inspires a question: Are we in a bubble?

Bubble Psychology

In the 1630s, tulips were not getting any prettier or more useful, but people bid them up because they believed they'd be able to sell them to someone else at an even higher price. Aka the “greater fool” theory. Meme stocks could best be defined as the greatest fool theory, as many buyers are convinced they are part of a movement. Pro tip: If someone tells you to “stick it to the man,” you are usually the stick. These kinds of bubbles are fragile, and they rarely get large in terms of the broader economy or last very long.

Bubbleicious

Multitrillion-dollar, economy-distorting bubbles occur when pure bubble psychology overlaps with real economic potential. This manifests as a self-propulsion machine — stock price increases validate assumptions and encourage more aggressive projections, which draws more speculators, who don't want to miss out, and so on, and so on. Exogenous factors including low interest rates (ie cheap money) can fuel them, but bubbles typically have an economic growth engine and an enduring technology at their core:

  • The dot-com bubble of the late 90s was predicated on a thesis that proved out: The internet was the most transformative technology of this millennium, poised to create unprecedented value. That did happen, and several of the companies that appeared wildly overvalued turned out to have been bargains.
  • The housing market bubble of the 2000s was a function of low interest rates, financialization, and other external factors, but under all that was a correct thesis: Land is finite, houses are essential, and we don't have enough of them. Nearly two decades later, we still don't.
  • Crypto was a bubble largely fueled by psychological nonsense — the Bored Apes should have been called Bored Tulips. But blockchain technology made a case for providing real benefit, and the resilience of Bitcoin indicates it likely will endure as a store of value.

The Bubble This Time

The financial media will digress to one of its favorite games, “Is this a bubble or is AI for real?”答案是肯定的。 AI's economic promise feels real, obvious even. And that is what makes a bubble inevitable. Bubbles emerge in unexpected ways, for unpredictable reasons.大气泡以类似的方式膨胀。 A transformative innovation emerges, capital rushes in, valuations increase, speculators add fuel, the atmosphere heats, the bubble grows, the cheap capital supercharges growth, and the wheel turns.

Of course we are in a bubble now — how could we not be after the mind-blowing debut of ChatGPT? AI is amazing, but the bubble-multiplier effect is very much in play. According to the Economist :

The combined market value of Alphabet, Amazon, and Microsoft has jumped by $2.5trn during the ai boom. [This value creation] is 120 times the $20bn in revenue that generative AI is forecast to add to the cloud giants' sales in 2024.

That was in March. Now it's $3 trillion. So the market is valuing AI revenue at 150x. Pre-AI, Microsoft was valued at about 10x revenue, Alphabet at 5x, and Amazon at around 4x. Growing into this AI multiple will require these businesses to find another $500 billion in annual revenue among them, in addition to continued expansion of their non-AI business, the equivalent of adding more than Alphabet's revenue.

The darling of AI, Nvidia, has been painted into a corner of good problems. But, nonetheless, a corner. NYU prof Aswath Damodaran has calculated that Nvidia, to justify its valuation, will need not only to continue to dominate the market for AI chips, forecasted to grow aggressively, but also to dominate another market of similar scale. Think about this: Built into the price of Nvidia is the expectation the company will find another market as big as AI, and achieve similar dominance.

At the peak of the dot-com bubble, Google was a newcomer with the second-most-popular search engine, and Meta didn't exist. Today hundreds of AI startups aim to replicate that sort of success. One prominent VC tracks 1,400 AI startups, even in a tight VC investment climate . As the IPO pipeline widens, more firms will emerge … and submerge. Many will fail — it's a bubble — but not all.

There are two important questions regarding AI, and neither is “are we in a bubble?”我们是。 The important questions are “when will it pop” and “who will endure?”

快速致富

Timing a bubble's pop correctly is likely the fastest way to become a billionaire, as the move in your direction, and the leverage on capital, is violent. John Paulson's hedge fund made $15 billion timing the housing bubble in 2007 (including $4 billion for himself); Michael Burry made a few hundred million and had a movie made about him, The Big Short . But timing is everything, and aggressive short positions can also pop. Burry shorted Tesla in 2020 , only to watch it double before unloading his short … at the peak. George Soros took “ whopping losses ” shorting the dot-com market in 1999. Legendary investor Julian Robertson turned $8 million into $22 billion before he, too, bet against the dot-com bubble … and gave up on his play a month before it popped 。 Showing up early sunk Tiger Management. If that name sounds familiar, it's because Robertson subsequently staked Tiger Global, which suffered from PTSD — the firm lost $60 billion staying long on tech in 2022. The lesson(s) from investing history all point to one thing: Nobody has any idea. The way to get rich is slowly, buying the whole haystack via low-cost ETFs.但我离题了。

Public Service Announcement: Nobody knows what will happen — you should diversify and not try to time the market.

If I knew when the AI bubble was going to detonate, I wouldn't be discussing it here but selling everything to buy deeply out-of-the-money put options in MSFT, NVDA, and other AI stocks, cash out after the crash, and buy Australia. Alas, I'm more confident about how, vs. when, the pop will play out.

气袋

Airplanes follow flight patterns, calculated to maximize safety and passenger comfort while minimizing fuel use. Atmosphere is not a static medium, however, and sometimes planes encounter localized areas of rapid air movement, aka turbulence. A sudden downdraft can cause a plane to drop hundreds or thousands of feet in seconds, an event known as hitting an air pocket. Most are harmless, but strong downdrafts can be terrifying and dangerous. Just this week, a Singapore Air 777 dropped so sharply that one passenger was killed and six more sent to the hospital.

Modern airplanes recover from hitting an air pocket in seconds, but frothy markets take longer to find their footing. Here's one scenario: A major non-tech company (eg, Walmart, JPM, Procter & Gamble) will announce it is paring back on its AI initiatives. Shuttering its AI team, calling off a joint venture, etc. “We remain optimistic about the long-term impact of AI on our business, but we are not seeing the ROI initially projected and are scaling back our level of capital investment in this technology ”。 The same cycle that drove prices up will pare them, only faster: Analysts will identify which AI players were selling to the company, and every CEO on every earnings call that week will be asked if they're cutting back their AI spend. Trend reversals travel through earnings calls like cold viruses through kindergartens, and by the end of the month, no CEO will want to be on the last helicopter out of AI Saigon. AI stocks will decline, and once they do, speculators will begin selling, creating a stampede for the exits. Trillions of dollars in market cap erased in weeks. Someone will time it perfectly.大多数不会。

The air pocket that popped the dot-com bubble blew in from the east. On Friday, March 10, 2000, the Nasdaq hit 5,049. The next Monday, Japanese economic data showed the country's economy had contracted in the fourth quarter of 1999, and the bad news was enough to spook the speculative market. The day's downdraft hammered the Nasdaq to its fourth-biggest point loss ever. It wouldn't break 5,000 again for 15 years. The housing bubble hit its own air pocket seven years later, in March 2007, when mortgage lender New Century Financial collapsed. The market's momentum continued for a few months but peaked in October before spiraling toward Earth.

泡泡爆破

The collapse of a major bubble can have far-reaching effects. The collapse of the housing bubble in 2007 spread into the banking system in 2008 and threatened the global economy — if you're between the ages of 16 and 94, that will, hopefully, be the most significant financial event of your lifetime.

我们。希望。

The dot-com meltdown mostly hurt people who could afford it, who'd taken an eyes-wide-open risk. I knew a lot of them — 100 of them worked for me. We called half of them into a conference room and laid them off, which still nauseates me when I think about it. The sin was hiring them in the first place — zealous hiring is a hallmark of bubble economics, both a symptom and a cause in the self-reinforcing cycle of bubbles. They were (mostly) great people, but we'd bought the same trope as everyone else: If you hire them, it (revenue) will come. The same was true all over the Valley and in the mini-Valleys that had sprung up in the bubble (Silicon Alley in NYC, Silicon Forest in Seattle — there were even a few Silicon Prairies). As in every Patagonia vest recession, most of those who were laid off are highly educated, employable young people who went on to other opportunities. There were second-order effects as well. There was a mild recession in 2000, which was bad especially for people entering the workforce or hoping to retire, and telco firms that had banked on never-ending broadband expansion got crushed. The broader market decline pushed companies with heavy pension obligations into bankruptcy .

Right now, it feels like the AI bubble is more in dot-com territory than housing-crisis country. But the bigger it gets, the more leveraged we become, and the larger the blast radius. It would be healthy if some of the air came out in 2024, but Nvidia's monster quarter will likely keep inflating the sector.

思科

Timing the bubble's end is less interesting than looking past it. If AI is half the technological breakthrough it feels like, it's going to sustain long-term value creation … but where? One aspect of this bubble that's caught my attention recently is how similar the narrative we hear today about Nvidia is to what people said about Cisco during the dot-com runup. Cisco is/was a hardware company that makes a lot of the gear the internet runs on. In 1999 it was the ultimate “picks and shovels” play, the company every tech fund had to have in its portfolio, and the stock you owned if you considered yourself a serious investor, not a speculator. Let the kids buy Pets.com and Amazon. That's essentially the narrative on Nvidia today.

Only it turned out there was a lot of that “serious” money, and boring Cisco increased in price 40x between 1995 and 2000. When everything crashed in 2000, Cisco went with it. Though the smart buy took less of a beating than Amazon, and much less than Pets.com, which went out of business that fall.

Long term, Cisco did “OK,” staying in business and beating the Nasdaq through most of the 2000s, though it hasn't kept pace with Big Tech's surge since 2020. (Long-term comps to an index like this are rigged against individual stocks, since indexes benefit from survivorship bias .)

Was Cisco a better bet than Amazon?差远了。 In fact, if on March 10, 2000, the peak of the bubble, you'd put a tenth of your money into 10 of the riskiest dot-com stocks rather than Cisco, you would still have outperformed Cisco (and the broader market) by over 15x, as long as one of those risky stocks was Amazon.

流行音乐

There are plenty of differences between dot-com and AI, and between Cisco and Nvidia. For one, Nvidia's runup has been fueled by spectacular earnings growth as well as hype, while Cisco benefitted from the time-limited Y2K investment boom. But when the “safe choice” is one of the frothiest stocks, we are a) in a bubble, and b) no longer playing it safe. The market is not necessarily rational in the short term, but over the long term, risk and return align. If Nvidia is the sure thing in this market, then it will generate sure-thing returns — aka it will track the market. If you're expecting Amazon circa 1999-2024 returns from Nvidia, then you should also expect Pets.com risk. This is not your pilot speaking, but do buckle up and make sure your tray table is secured.

Over the past several decades, America has waged a covert war against the young . One front in this war is our income tax system, which favors Owners over Earners. Young people are almost all Earners, while Owners are typically older, and the tax code is a wealth-transfer vehicle for Owners to garner a greater share of our common wealth.好消息？ It can be changed … back.

Pwned

If you get a paycheck, whether it's salary or freelance, and that's how you pay your bills, you're an Earner. Owners, on the other hand, might collect wage income, but their real money comes through profits from investments: stock sales and dividends, rent from property , and other income streams derived from the ownership of assets. To be an Earner is noble; you work for a living, and labor is a sacred thing. Labor is the source of food, shelter, entertainment, and every material pleasure of society. We even celebrate it with a holiday, the first Monday in September. Pro tip: If you want to celebrate Labor Day somewhere awesome, try as hard as you can to become an Owner.

Owners also get a celebratory day. It's April 15. Another pro tip: If you're ever featured in a commercial calling you a “hero,” it means you're getting fucked. The most fortunate in our society have no holiday, as they don't need one. They recognize that holidays wallpaper over the inequity faced by anybody who gets a day in their honor.

Income taxes for Earners are deceptively straightforward. Take your annual income, subtract the standard deduction ($24,000 for a married couple), make a few other calculations, and then pay a percentage of what's left to Uncle Sam. And the income tax rates for most people are low: A two-adult household making less than $100,000 per year pays 10% or less in federal income tax. Many pay much less, or none at all.听起来很合理，对吧？但有一个问题。 Several … catches.

First, for those paying “only” 10% or less of their wages in income taxes, other forms of tax are a heavier burden. At the federal level, Social Security and Medicare add almost 8%. Then all states collect taxes, and most state tax systems are “regressive.” All told, lower-income people pay a greater portion of their income in taxes than many rich people.

Sales tax, property tax, and other government revenue sources (licensing fees, permits and filing fees, and car registrations) take a larger bite out of lower-income households. In “low-tax” Florida, the most regressive state, low-income families (Earners) pay 13.2% of their income in state and local taxes, the middle class pays 9.1%, and the top 1% (Owners) pays just 2.7 %。 In fact, lower- and middle-income Florida households pay about the same in total taxes as they would in “high-tax” California. The next time you hear someone complain about low-income people who “don't pay any taxes,” remind them that income tax doesn't exist in a vacuum — low-income people often pay over 25% of their income in taxes.

There's a myth that the rich don't pay their fair share of taxes. The reality is most “rich” people — the super-earners — pay more than their fair share. A married household making more than $500,000 per year is in the top 5% of households by income and pays an effective federal income tax rate around 25%. Half a million dollars may seem like a lot, but careers that pay that well require expensive college and graduate degrees, entail long hours, offer little job security, and they're typically in high-cost-of-living locations with high state income tax — in New York or California, add another 10% on to that 25%. With other taxes, including sales tax, thetotal tax burden borne by mid-career professionals can reach 40% of their income. The baller who makes seven figures plus is often working for the government: Their (total) effective tax burden can approach 50%. Until, that is, they can make the jump to lightspeed (ie, become an Owner).

Think of building wealth as launching a rocket ship into orbit. Rockets burn 95% of their fuel to escape Earth's soupy atmosphere and incessant gravity. Once you get to orbit, you're a master of the universe — covering thousands of miles with just a touch of propulsion. Wealth is similar. The atmosphere is your expenses; the distance traveled, your income. Most of us never generate enough current income to make the jump to space and become an Owner — save enough to invest so our primary source(s) of income are passive. Investing is difficult, if not impossible at low income levels. Saving your first $100,000 is incredibly hard. The next $100,000 is tough, but you now have momentum and start to see the curvature of the Earth. Once your current income is substantially greater than your expenses, and you've deployed an army of capital that fights for you and your family in your sleep, you've made the jump. What we've done with the tax code has rendered the atmosphere thicker and gravity stronger. Go to law or medical school, or live at the office, and you'll see your (current) income increase, but you'll also lose a bigger share to taxes, and the harder it gets to save and escape the gravity of being an Earner.

轨道

Imagine if taxes worked like this: Everything you spend that's remotely related to work is deducted from your taxable income. Clothes you wear and food you eat during the work week, your car, your internet and cellphone bills, furniture and square footage where you work at home (eg, kitchen table), etc., all taken off your income before taxes. Pretty much anything you do on days you're working, deductible. All past investments in education, deductible. If you spent more than you earned, as you did in college and graduate schools, you can roll over those losses as deductions in future years. In the meantime, deduct any credit card interest you're paying. Any money you don't spend? That's not taxed until you retire and start spending it. If you give it to your kids, it's never taxed at all.

If this sounds familiar but awkward, it is. It's our tax code, through the lens of the Owner. The federal income tax code looks progressive: The highest marginal tax rate is 37%, more than 3x what the average American pays. But published tax rates are a weapon of mass distraction. They are the “rack rate” published on the door of your hotel room. Owners never pay the rack rate. They barely pay at all.

Unlike Earners' taxes, Owners' taxes are complex. As a result, determining the total tax burden of the very wealthy is difficult, but here's what we know: In 2020 the 26,000 households with an income over $10 million paid 25.5% of their reported income in federal taxes, plus 5% to 10% in state and local taxes. But as I explain below, much of the cash they receive isn't taxable income, and most of the increase in Owners' wealth is never taxed at all. The White House has estimated that the 400 wealthiest households pay an effective income tax rate of just 8.2%, and Pro Publica found that the wealthiest 25 households pay just 3.4%. We can't say for sure what percent Owners pay on average, but it's less than most of their employees pay. This complexity results in a transfer of wealth from Earners to Owners. The tax code has exploded from 400 to 4,000 pages in the past few decades. If you have GPS (advisers, loopholes for the wealthy), you want races run at night.

If the government is meant to decrease suffering and add happiness, then our current system makes no sense. Paying taxes of $5 million on $10 million in income is the difference between flying first class and flying private. Paying $15,000 on $60,000 in income might mean foregoing a second child.

Capitalism means accepting a society of winners and losers.没关系。 Wealth is a great reward for hard work, and talent is what drives us to create value. Capitalism has brought prosperity to billions over the past 150 years. The problem is the system, if left unchecked, becomes increasingly inequitable and unsustainable. We've morphed from capitalism to cronyism, rigged in favor of Owners.如何？ Three ways: calculation, timing, and collection.

计算

Amateurs focus on tax rates . Professionals zero in on the calculation of the income to which those rates apply. In the 1950s the highest federal income tax bracket was 91%. Except nobody paid it . The tax code was a mosaic of loopholes, ensuring high-income taxpayers were able to shield most of their income. Now the top rate is 37%, but while the colors and fabric have changed, the Owner's tapestry of tax avoidance still exists.

Owners receive cash from a range of sources: rent from tenants, dividends from stock, interest from loans, distributions from trusts, profits from investment partnerships, loans and lines of credit from banks, proceeds from asset sales, and more. Much of this income is shielded by pages of tax code defining what is, and is not, taxable. Owners who invest in the oil business leverage tax code provision section 263 (intangible drilling costs), section 613 (percentage depletion), section 611 (cost depletion), section 167 (geological expenses), section 199 (domestic production deduction), section 193 (tertiary injectant expenses), and section 469 (active losses). That's just one industry.

Entrepreneurs are barely visible to the Treasury standing behind the tax code. Section 1202 excludes the first $10 million received in the sale of a business, a provision that saved me millions of dollars when I sold my firm L2 several years ago. When working at the firm — earning — I was paying 40+% taxes. But when I sold the business, my tax rate on the proceeds — owning — was 17%. Even before selling, every small business owner gets an enormous shield, the power to push all manner of personal expenses through the company income statement, thus making them tax deductions for the business rather than taxable income for the Owner.

Income that's acquired by selling an asset for more than you paid for it is a capital gain, and isn't subject to ordinary income tax rates. Capital gains rates (federal) max out at 23.8% instead of 37%. That's still not the biggest loophole. Capital gains are only taxed when “realized” (typically when sold), so Owners' assets grow tax deferred (some you can depreciate as they go up in value) and their sales are timed to minimize taxes. Earners lose 20% to 50% of their gains (from sweat) every year, a massive gravitational pull. Owners enjoy cleaner propulsion: As their wealth grows, the taxes are deferred until they sell … if they ever do.

但等等，还有更多。 The biggest tax break Owners can register is dying, which resets the “basis” of their assets, so their heirs never pay taxes on the increase in value. Still, there's more. The most indefensible loophole award goes to the “ carried interest loophole ” which permits investment fund managers to pay capital gains rates on their compensation. Tax policy groups have been lobbying to close this loophole for years, and Congress nearly did it in 2022, but Senator Kyrsten Sinema took $2 million from the private equity industry (aka Owners) and saved their $14 billion loophole. It's well known that our leaders are whores. What's more surprising, and disappointing, is what cheap whores they are ($2 million for $14 billion).但我离题了。

Owners are so tax-advantaged that if they do have earned income, they often shield that from taxation as well. Donald Trump paid virtually no income taxes on the $427 million he made from The Apprentice — where he had an actual job — by offsetting that cash income with paper losses on his real estate properties (real estate is another of the most tax-advantaged industries) 。 In 2007, Jeff Bezos made $46 million in actual income, yet he paid zero dollars in federal income tax, because he was able to shield that income with paper losses as an Owner (in reality, his wealth increased $3.8 billion that year). In 2011, not only did Bezos pay no income tax again, he claimed and received a $4,000 child tax credit — a program intended to lower child poverty. If you paid federal income tax in 2011, you helped feed Jeff Bezos's kids. Don't worry, he's fine .

定时

A key advantage of control over timing is state income tax arbitrage, practiced often by company founders. Several years ago, the media discovered the phenomenon of California entrepreneurs moving to Texas and Florida, and there was a lot of jazz hands about those states' friendly business climates and youthful energy. The truth was simpler: Texas and Florida have no state income tax, and many of those founders were about to recognize enormous gains via sales of stock that had become worth billions. Elon Musk, who moved to Texas in 2020, sold millions of shares of Tesla, saving an estimated $2.5 billion in California income tax. When Washington State enacted a tax on income from asset sales, Jeff Bezos decided to spend more time with his father in Florida, which has no income tax, and sold 50 million shares of Amazon after he relocated. If taking advantage of Washington's schools, roads, and tech ecosystem to build wealth, and then declining to pay taxes back to the state sounds wrong — and a massive additional burden on middle-class taxpayers who can't peace out to Coral Gables — trust your instincts.

The best time to pay taxes is never , using the infamous “ Buy, Borrow, Die ” tax strategy. Wealthy Owners take out loans secured by assets such as company stock or real estate, and live off the loans (which are not considered taxable income) instead of selling the assets (which would incur a taxable gain). When the Owner dies, the stock goes to their heirs, who, with their “stepped up basis,” can sell enough stock tax-free to pay off the loans and start the cycle anew. This creates dynastic wealth, the lack of which used to be a key point of differentiation between Europe and the US Used to be.

收藏

All of these strategies are legal and enabled by the complexity of the tax code. But that complexity also affords Owners another means of avoidance: cheating.

Skirting taxes stems from the complexity of the tax code itself. Wealthy filers can take deductions that don't apply or classify income in inappropriate ways. And without an exhaustive analysis of the facts, there's no way for the IRS to determine what they've done.特朗普用来抵消《学徒》收入的一些损失可能是非法的——美国国税局认为，他两次在芝加哥的一个房地产项目上申报了数亿美元的损失，将双底探底埋在了堆积如山的税务文件之下。美国国税局花了十年的时间来挖掘它。

业主还可以选择明目张胆地作弊，不报告大量收入并编造虚假的费用和损失。这是纽约酒店经营者利昂娜·赫尔姆斯利的策略。在因逃税入狱之前，她对管家说：“我们不纳税；我们不纳税；我们不纳税。”只有小人物才纳税。”离岸实体是一种历史悠久的逃税策略。特朗普的竞选经理保罗·马纳福特 (Paul Manafort) 在外国银行账户中隐瞒了来自国税局 (IRS) 的1650 万美元收入。

税收减免

解决这些不平等问题远没有解决美国面临的许多其他挑战那么困难。最明显、最明显的补救措施是为国税局提供资金，使其能够收取数千亿美元的欠税但未缴纳。 《降低通货膨胀法案》原本应在未来 10 年内向国税局拨款 800 亿美元，但共和党人对该措施提出了攻击，从该计划中削减了200 亿美元，并在 2024 年保持国税局预算持平。每投资 1 美元，就针对富人的税收执法返回12 美元的收入。需要明确的是，这不是骚扰，而是强制执行。大多数外部性都是激励的函数，政府激励业主在纳税申报表上表现得异常积极，因为他们被抓住的机会很小。如果你在没有警察的高速公路上，你会超速吗？

取消对资本利得的特殊待遇是一个简单的解决办法，可以在不增加大多数美国人税收负担的​​情况下增加税收收入，减少通过错误分类作弊的动机，并使税收制度更加公平。取消继承的累进基础也是如此，它抹去了最富有的人所欠的数十亿税款，几乎没有任何理由或社会效益。我们应该取消社会保障税的收入上限（目前微不足道的 16 万美元），这将有助于支撑社会保障信托基金，并使税法（而不是税率）更加累进。我们应该将（业主）最高边际税率恢复到40%。拜登和国会民主党人近年来提出了所有这些改变，但都无济于事。

由于所有权具有一些固有的税收优势， 交易税将以公平的方式增加所有权收入。包括迈克·布隆伯格 (Mike Bloomberg)在内的众多提议，对证券交易和其他金融交易征收 0.1% 的税，每年可能筹集近 800 亿美元的资金，其潜在的附带好处是抑制高频交易，从而增加波动性，而不会给市场带来好处。我们还应该对云和人工智能服务征收计算税，因为这些创新创造的财富主要归最富有的所有者所有。计算是新能源，这是避免化石燃料错误的一个机会，我们为业主提供税收减免，并向收入者征收汽油税，这是我们系统中最具累退性的附加费之一。

最后，最具变革性的是，国会应该对税法实施电锯，削减游说者塞给所有者阶层的数千份救济金。从理论上讲，找到政治意愿应该不难，因为大多数美国人都被代表少数同胞的立法者搞砸了。具有讽刺意味的是，特朗普的减税政策为这一变化铺平了道路——通过将标准扣除额加倍，特朗普确保只有10% 的纳税人接受逐项扣除——这意味着 90% 的选民应该支持取消其余部分。尽管如此，这可能是一个挑战，因为所有者拥有的最有价值的资产……是国会。

我们应该将这些变化每年获得的数千亿美元中的一部分进行再投资，以使该系统对赚钱者（即年轻人）更加公平：

  • 扩大儿童税收抵免和收入所得税抵免，并提高缴纳任何税款所需的下限。 （目前，单身/已婚家庭的标准扣除额为 14,600 美元/29,200 美元。）这将使更多低收入家庭免受联邦所得税的影响，并减少累退性州税和地方税的影响。
  • 降低收入较高但不是最高收入的纳税人的税率，那些每周工作 60 小时爬上职业阶梯的专业人士和企业家不应该获得 45% 的税收负担。这将使获得所有权（又名美国梦）的途径变得更加可行。

以下是一组粗略修订的括号，随着执法力度的加大和特朗普对企业减税政策的取消，我们应该能够获得相同或更多的收入：

爱国者

我对远离爱国主义的趋势感到困扰，这种趋势是由科技亿万富翁阶层煽动的，他们将运气与天赋混为一谈，对美国进行垃圾邮件，并对年轻人发动经济战。但美国的承诺只有得到实绩的支持才能引起共鸣。当我们不谈论美国的问题时，我们就削弱了美国的伟大之处。特别是当修复在我们的掌握之中时。

为了保护业主，游说者和我们在华盛顿的代表认为，富人是我们最具生产力的公民，可以更好地部署资本，并且需要激励措施来不断创新。这个观点有一定道理，但我们并没有降低对当今大部分创新者、超级收入者或未来创新者、年轻人的税收。相反，我们通过将更多财富转移给业主/老年人来确保启动失败。税收凳子的三足是公司、超级收入者和超级所有者。公司税处于 1939 年以来的最低水平，最富有的美国人正在缴纳个位数的税率，这意味着我们国家的全部资金负担都落在了超级收入者和年轻人身上，他们将不得不在我们的债务海啸中生存下来。正在聚集起来为这种不平等提供资金。这是资本主义在自身重压下崩溃的结果。

与任何国家一样，美国是一种产品——多种利益的组合，但需要付出一定的代价。三个世纪以来的大部分时间里，美国一直是（全球）最具价值的国家。除了毒品之外，没有任何一种产品能让这么多人愿意冒着生命危险去获取。然而，对于超级收入者和年轻人来说，美国的价值已经下降。我们向前者收取过高的费用，并不断询问后者是否可以借用他们的信用卡。坏消息？这是我们深思熟虑的决定。好消息？我们可以决定修复它。

爱因斯坦用质量是能量的一种形式这一启示来定义了 20 世纪。今天的理论物理学提出了一些更基本的假设：质量和能量都是信息。 21 世纪的定义是认识到最强大的能源形式是信息操纵：计算。控制计算的公司将成为历史上最具主导地位的企业。

从经济诞生之初，能源就是摇动每只狗的尾巴。然而，现在股市的说法是，大型石油公司已将控制权交给了大型科技公司。这是一个实际观察：1980 年和 2024 年大多数最有价值的公司分别属于能源和科技行业。然而，数英亩数据中心的建设以及为其供电所需的能源投资反映了更深层次的融合。人工智能正在加速大型科技公司从销售计算机的行业向销售计算的行业的转型。在知识经济中，计算就是能源。

充电

一万年前，能源是唯一的产业。世界靠肌肉力量运转，而食物就是能量来源。肥沃的中东地区的定居农业创造了盈余，经济学作为盈余交易的科学而出现——交换能源。然后，我们释放了有机物（木材、煤炭、石油）中的能量，机器取代了肌肉，能源业务变成了为机器提供动力的业务。石油是无与伦比的机器动力原材料，使沙漠成为富裕国家。大型科技公司可能在市值排行榜上占据主导地位，但能源仍然是收入之王。 按收入计算，前 10 家公司中有 6 家是能源公司，该行业产生的收入比其他任何行业都多。然而……科技每年看起来都与能源更加相似。

资本支出 = 护城河 = 利润

能源业务需要大量的资本支出，分配在数据和信仰上，为那些下注正确的人提供无与伦比的回报。如果说捕鲸业是风险投资的起源，那么能源就是资本支出的原始黑帮。到 2024 年，所有能源的投资总额将达到2.8 万亿美元。化石燃料公司的资本支出占其中 1 万亿美元，创造的收入为 4 万亿美元。埃克森美孚 2023 年资本支出达230 亿美元，利润达 360 亿美元。投资金额巨大：英国最新的核电站正在萨默塞特建设，预计耗资 570 亿美元。规划 20 世纪的大型能源项目需要开发一门新的预测科学，即壳牌著名的“ 情景规划”流程。旁注：情景规划不是预测未来，而是确定哪些决策将在几种可能的未来中获得最佳结果。

现在，大型科技公司正在展示自己的技术。到 2024 年，科技巨头将花费芬兰的国内生产总值（3000 亿美元，或多或少），主要用于数据中心——相当于现代的油田开发。 Alphabet 仅上一季度就支出了 120 亿美元，同比增长 90%，微软支出 140 亿美元，增长 79%，亚马逊支出 140 亿美元。科技领域尚未与全球能源投资相匹配，但就个别而言，Alphabet、亚马逊、Meta 和微软今年的资本支出将超过埃克森美孚、雪佛龙或沙特阿美公司。 Meta 运营着 18 个数据中心，覆盖区域与19 个迪士尼乐园相同。拉斯维加斯的 Core 是世界上最大的数据中心之一，有自己的宣传视频。 （大约 1 分钟后，它变得……令人印象深刻。）

大型科技公司的利润也是历史性的，而且还在不断增长。上周， Alphabet 的利润超出预期 25%，市值增加了 2000 亿美元（达到 2 万亿美元）， 苹果公司在盈利超出预期并宣布回购 1100 亿美元的股票后，市值也增加了 2000 亿美元。 2023 年，两家公司的净利润都超过了埃克森美孚，微软也是如此。

更多，我想要更多

能源公司可以证明这些投资是合理的，因为我们对能源使用的想象力是无限的。大能量铁律：我们产生的越多，我们使用的就越多。没有太多的能量。能量是 GLP-1 药物的对立面。对于能量，我们消耗的越多，我们就越饥饿。

能源=繁荣

财富和能源消耗是相关的。它不仅是奢侈生活方式的动力，也是生产力：照明、烹饪和储存食物、通信网络、建筑、交通。学术界对最佳人均能源消耗的估计仅呈上升趋势。再多的节能微波炉和双层玻璃窗也无法抵挡数十亿进入中产阶级的消费：预计到 2050 年，全球能源消耗将增加 44% 。

科技的胃口也是无法满足的。科技的铁律是摩尔定律：处理能力每两年翻一番。撇开技术细节不谈，这个原则自 1965 年以来一直适用。“我们将如何使用这种力量？”从来没有询问过任何人。英特尔是我的第一家公司 Prophet 的客户，其独特的战略愿景给我们留下了深刻的印象。他们在制造工厂投入了大量资本支出，生产他们没有发明的芯片，用于他们没有想象到的应用。总之，“如果我们建造它，他们就会来。直到苹果向世界展示图形用户界面，直到网景浏览网页，直到上帝（谷歌）开始以数百万个答案回应任何祈祷/询问，或者直到一个新的上帝（ChatGPT）回应你的信息，没有人需要更快的芯片。祈祷只有一个答案。英特尔在向移动领域的转型中遇到了挫折，但范式并没有改变。不存在太多计算这样的事情。

新新能源

大型科技不仅类似于能源业务，而且是新能源业务。人工智能不断增长的电力需求使这一点变得具体。人工智能计算需求每 100 天就会翻一番，这极大地抵消了每个人工智能传播者在吐槽人工智能将拯救/毁灭人类后所吹嘘的效率提升。训练在一个中等城市（旧金山）酝​​酿的数万亿参数模型需要消耗一个小国家的能源。一个 ChatGPT 请求需要10 倍于 Google 搜索的能量。五年内，人工智能增量能源需求将相当于4000 万户家庭的能源需求，超过加利福尼亚州、德克萨斯州、佛罗里达州和纽约州的总和。数据中心占美国总电力需求的 3%，但预计到 2030 年将增加两倍。顺便说一句，2030 年与过去的《权力的游戏》结局（2019 年）一样遥远。

为了满足数据中心的需求，科技公司正在投资数十亿美元用于能源生产和存储。据《华尔街日报》 报道，大型科技公司的高管们纷纷出席今年的年度石油和天然气会议，寻找能源。比尔盖茨是特邀演讲者。亚马逊是可再生能源最大的企业买家，拥有超过500 个正在运营或正在开发的项目。新数据中心的宣布同时还承诺开发新的风能和太阳能发电厂来提供电力。

计算 = 能量2

技术与能源的融合反映了技术从销售计算工具到销售计算本身的转变。我们不购买 DVD 播放器和光盘，我们购买流媒体。我们不买地图，我们得到路线。我们不购买胶卷，我们捕捉图像。苹果是历史上最赚钱的产品公司，其增长依赖于服务。亚马逊（零售界的苹果）是一家提供零售服务的数据中心企业。

人工智能将这一趋势推向所有事物和每个人。历史上最赚钱的业务搜索将被答案取代。电子表格和浏览器将被代理取代。 “应用程序”和“程序”将是由其他代理产生的可变的、不断进化的代码有机体。能源会议主讲人比尔盖茨表示：“代理将影响我们使用软件的方式以及软件的编写方式。 ……它们将取代文字处理程序、电子表格和其他生产力应用程序。今天独立的业务——搜索广告、广告社交网络、购物、生产力软件——将成为一项业务。” Sam Altman 相信计算将成为“未来的货币”，世界上最珍贵的商品。

21世纪，人类为物理学翻开了新的一页，一种新形式的能源：计算。正如我们的身体将食物的化学能转化为热能和机械能，太阳能电池板将太阳的电磁能转化为电能，数据中心将电能转化为计算能力，为数字经济提供动力。与其他形式的能源一样，计算是由世界上最大的公司创建的，这些公司拥有惊人的资本来建造亚马逊河（河流）宽度的护城河。与其他形式的能源一样，其消费与繁荣和增长有着千丝万缕的联系。计算违背了经济引力——供应增加带动了需求。能源的未来不是可再生的，而是可计算的。

No Free Lunch

火炬从能源到科技的传递在炎热的一分钟里感觉很好，因为能源已经与它的阴暗面接触太多了。能源公司发明了“外部性”一词：碳、腐败和西斯尊主的资本主义。相比之下，科技感觉更好。马克、谢丽尔、拉里、谢尔盖和杰夫太可爱了，太可爱了，不可能那么邪恶……他们甚至告诉我们他们不会做坏事。杰夫的笑声，谢丽尔靠过来，马克拿着弓箭狩猎：

只是。他妈的。可爱的。

但后来孩子们开始伤害自己，错误信息激增，我们的谈话变得粗俗。等等……科技巨头并不比石油巨头更好，他们更糟糕。事实上，它们都不是——它们是一样的。

为了经济利益而将一种物质与另一种物质进行套利会产生排放。植物到牛肉：甲烷。运动的化石燃料：碳。注意广告：愤怒。相信计算的巨大套利不会产生非凡的外部性，就等于相信扎克伯格/桑德伯格/布林/贝索斯会优先考虑联邦的福祉而不是他们的财富。如果我们可以回到 100 年前化石燃料时代的开始，或者 20 年前社会的开始，我们会采取什么不同的做法？

许多人认为，大型科技是资本主义在自身重压下崩溃的结果。失去对纯种马的控制的骑师。调节计算类似于 5 英尺高、110 磅重的骑师骑着霸王龙。我们知道这会很笨拙。更大的问题是，这会是暴力吗？

生活如此丰富，

任何物种要想生存下去，就必须在两件事上找到回报：性和冲突。性欲的重要性是显而易见的。但如果我们不生冲突，我们就会遭遇与从未繁衍同样的命运。进化是资源的竞争，冲突是不可避免的。生态系统不太关心谁公平竞争：一切事物都是其他事物的牺牲品；一切事物都是其他事物的牺牲品。冲突会因资源、配偶、领地和骄傲而产生。我们要么开发出一个巧妙地选择战斗的奖励系统，要么我们就会被一个这样做的物种所吞噬。

人类也不能幸免。我们进化成躲在树上，而更强大、更快、爪子更锋利的生物则在大草原上漫步。因此，我们开发了一个强大的神经系统，用于识别威胁、衡量其严重性并快速做出响应，通常是在我们意识到威胁级别之前。但战斗或逃跑并不足以带领我们逃离森林。首先，我们必须发展我们的超级大国：合作。使我们成为顶级掠食者的鸡尾酒是在冲突的岩石上进行合作。在威胁之下，我们成为“兄弟连”，建立“姐妹情谊”，“对抗强权”，形成“一个国家，不可分割”。

爱你的敌人

然而，该系统始终处于开启状态。害怕的感觉不好，但生气的感觉却很好。当我们周围的人证实了我们的愤怒并将其引向所选择的威胁时，效果尤其好。这种动态通常被称为“部落主义”，但这没有抓住要点。部落是由他们的敌人定义的。他们帮助我们将危险和焦虑转化为兄弟情谊和荣耀。精神领袖宣扬我们应该爱我们的敌人。进化论告诉我们要喜欢有敌人。

在共同敌人的威胁下争取支持是一种古老的策略。历史上的宿敌雅典和斯巴达联合起来对抗波斯帝国，而罗马与迦太基的竞争被认为是将其难以驾驭的共和国团结在一起的功劳。美国制定了半个世纪的应对共产主义威胁的外交政策。最深刻的是，史塔克家族和坦格利安军队联手对抗不死族。但我离题了。

我们喜欢冲突。正如李将军在弗雷德里克斯堡所说：“战争如此可怕是好事，否则我们应该变得太喜欢战争了。”在今天，这一点可能更是如此，因为技术和文化已经切断了我们许多传统的纽带，让年轻人渴望联系和社区。根据联合国儿童基金会最近的一份报告，“愿意参加示威活动的人数比例已增加至20世纪90年代以来的最高水平，这一时期的抗议活动数量也有所增加。”

了解你的敌人

大多数竞争都是无害的，但它们指向了一个更黑暗的传统。因为我们在面对威胁时团结一致，所以我们会寻找敌人，即使我们需要制造敌人。或者我们让别人为我们制造它们。寻找替罪羊是煽动者手册中的首选。

本周，唐纳德·特朗普告诉《时代》杂志，他将考虑部署军队打击美国境内的移民，并将无证入境视为“入侵”。他声称，“过去三周，有 29,000 人从中国来到这里，他们都在抗争年龄，而且大多数是男性。”他说得对，穿越南部边境的中国移民人数急剧增加——事实上，已有数千人到达纽约。 《纽约时报》一直在记录他们的到来。

但需要用扭曲的视角来看待这些人中的敌人，他们睡在双层床上，从事美国公民不想要的危险/肮脏的工作。我看到我的父母冒着一切风险去寻找更好的生活。而且，这些新移民是我们的生命线。 2021年，他们缴纳了5000亿美元的税款，占所有企业家的22%。他们的孩子是美国财政生产力最高的群体。如果没有移民，我们的人口就会下降，这是陷入衰退并失去全球舞台影响力的最可靠方式。

在校园

加沙冲突在整个美国高等教育界引起了反响，让许多人措手不及，尽管有预测称学术界将出现混乱，而且 DEI 将开始自食其果并变得种族主义。美国大学有抗议的重要遗产。然而，这些校园抗议活动中存在令人不安的反犹太主义。其程度存在争议且不清楚，但它正在发生，历史告诉我们，不存在“反犹太主义之光”这样的东西。虽然所有形式的偏执都应受到谴责，但反犹太主义具有独特的危险，因为长期以来一直将犹太人视为首选的、人为的敌人。对于任何倡导某种事业的团体来说，积极打击任何利用我们识别假敌人的原始本能的仇恨信息是至关重要的。我相信美国面临的最大威胁不是它真正的对手，而是那些告诉我们要伤害那些不构成真正危险的人的声音。离开图书馆去修指甲的犹太女孩并不是你的死敌。这些仇恨信息之所以具有如此强大的力量，是因为它们触发了我们深层的敌人识别系统。

我们加入运动是因为他们的目标，但也越来越多地因为加入让我们感觉良好。这并不是一种侮辱——加入是我们做一切事情的原因；它以某种方式触发我们的奖励系统。在大学庭院或路障建筑上露营是一种社交春药。这些经历产生了强烈的共同认同感，并给我们带来了我们渴望的强烈的“ 归属感”——尤其是对于那些缺乏前几代人在校园里享有的结缔组织的年轻人来说。新冠疫情和身份政治使学生彼此隔离和分裂。

还有加州大学洛杉矶分校的

周二晚上，在我的母校加州大学洛杉矶分校，反抗议者袭击了亲巴勒斯坦营地，随后发生了长达数小时的激战。这与加沙的人道主义危机没有任何关系。非洲有句谚语：如果孩子感受不到部落的拥抱，他们就会把它烧毁来感受温暖。我不知道有多少学生抗议者焚烧村庄来感受温暖。当热情压倒理性分析时，你会发现自己在大学行政大楼的台阶上要求： “革命应该得到满足。”我们应该而且将会对那些挑战知识自由和测试极限的 19 岁年轻人敬而远之。换句话说，他们付钱给我们，让我们在安全的环境中犯错误。然而，当他们的言论损害了其他学生获得安全大学经历的权利时，他们应该被停学或开除。

在加州大学洛杉矶分校，他们在申请过程中驱逐了 91% 的（潜在）学生。限制犹太人使用校园设施难道不应该等同于没有完美的 SAT 考试吗？精英大学需要接受和退出更多的学生。最后，在我看来，任何教师或管理人员都没有理由破坏我们的教育使命。他们有言论自由的权利，这意味着他们不会因为自己的言论而受到刑事指控。然而，这些是成年人，他们拿薪水来做一份工作，当他们让我们其他人的工作变得更加困难，或者让学生及其家人甚至举行毕业典礼时， 他们就应该被解雇。

走进任何组织的大厅，开始对你的同事尖叫，并在自助餐厅搭起一个帐篷，看看结果如何。精英大学教师的傲慢和自我膨胀，单方面将自己的职位描述改为“社会工程师”，令人讨厌。你在学院支票的背面而不是正面签名——做好你该死的工作。

愚蠢的

加州大学伯克利分校教授卡洛·西波拉 (Carlo Cippolla) 开发了一种巧妙的概念来识别“愚蠢”的人：伤害他人的同时也伤害自己。我们所有人，在人生的不同阶段，都是愚蠢的。我们本能地背叛父母（即，当我们十几岁的时候），因为这样更容易脱离群体，而且质疑做事的方式是健康的。 “我恨你！”每个青少年都这么说……在某个时候。我们也容易变得愚蠢，对配偶和朋友缺乏礼貌。仇恨和嫉妒类似于 Wi-Fi：超本地化。关心我们的人常常首当其冲地承受我们的情绪和失望，而这些与他们无关。校园里的学生对自己的国家怀有敌意，更不用说他们的同学了，他们正在伤害他人和自己。
